linkTarget.anchoringText: Foam flooding theory (Rossen, Zhou, & Mamun, 1995) (Khatib, Hirasaki, & Falls, 1988) (Alvarez, Rivas, & Rossen, 2001) describes well the rheological behavior of foam in a model porous media, i.e. foam flow in a homogeneous core or sandpack in isothermal conditions under constant back-pressure and in absence of oil. Figure 1 represents a typical sandpack or coreflood setup.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Schematic representation of a sandpack or coreflood setup

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic representation of a sandpack or coreflood setup

linkTarget.anchoringText: To evaluate foam rheological behavior, different interstitial velocities should be explored. The evolution of apparent viscosity with interstitial velocity at fixed foam quality is presented in Figure 2. We make a distinction between weak foams with moderate to low apparent viscosity, having Newtonian behavior and strong foam which can exhibit high apparent viscosities. Strong foams show an increase in apparent viscosity with interstitial velocity until the critical interstitial velocity vi* is reached. Above vi*, foam has an average shear thinning behavior.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Schematic representation of the evolution of the apparent viscosity of foam as a function of interstitial velocity in both strong (black) and weak (blue) foam regimes at fixed foam quality

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic representation of the evolution of the apparent viscosity of foam as a function of interstitial velocity in both strong (black) and weak (blue) foam regimes at fixed foam quality

linkTarget.anchoringText: The evolution of apparent viscosity with foam quality at fixed interstitial velocity is presented in Figure 3. Two regimes are described for strong foams: low foam quality regime and high foam quality regime (Alvarez 2001). In the high foam quality regime, insufficient lamellae stabilization leads to continuous gas paths in the porous media. The flow is dominated by coalescence. In the low quality regime, foam flows as gas bubbles separated by liquid lamellae, which are stable toward coalescence and the flow is dominated by bubble trapping and lamellae displacement.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Schematic representation of the evolution of the apparent viscosity of foam as a function of foam quality at fixed interstitial velocity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic representation of the evolution of the apparent viscosity of foam as a function of foam quality at fixed interstitial velocity

linkTarget.anchoringText: Main sulfonate surfactants structures are presented in Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Various sulfonate surfactant structures used for steam foam applications. (a) Alkyl sulfonates. (b) Alkylaryl sulfonates. Alfa and internal olefin sulfonates are a mixture of the two structures represented.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Various sulfonate surfactant structures used for steam foam applications. (a) Alkyl sulfonates. (b) Alkylaryl sulfonates. Alfa and internal olefin sulfonates are a mixture of the two structures represented.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot pattern was composed of 4 contiguous inverted 5-spots (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Map of the Mecca steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the Mecca steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: The response to the foam injection was obvious from the increase in injection pressure that was experienced. However, it took 2 years (0.37 PV) of injection before a significant production response was observed (Figure 6): the oil rate increase from 100 bopd up to a maximum of 375 bopd and remained high for several years even after the injection had stopped. Part of this response could be due to events in the area around the pilot. In particular, the long duration of the response is difficult to attribute to foam alone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Injection response in Mecca steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injection response in Mecca steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: In any case, changes in injection profile were clearly documented through several temperature surveys and neutron logs run in the wells at different points in time (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Improved vertical sweep - Mecca observation well TT2 (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Improved vertical sweep - Mecca observation well TT2 (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot pattern was also composed of 4 contiguous inverted 5-spots (Figure 8). Contrary to Mecca, the pattern had been under steamflood for only one year but prior to that had been under cyclic steam injection for 19 years.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Map of Bishop steam-foam pilot and nearby comparison pattern (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of Bishop steam-foam pilot and nearby comparison pattern (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: The response to the foam injection was obvious from the increase in injection pressure that was experienced. As in Mecca it took two years after the beginning of the surfactant injection for the oil rate to increase from 150 bopd up to a maximum of 375 bopd (Figure 9); however, it subsequently remained high for several years even after the injection had stopped. Part of this response could be due to events in the area around the pilot. In particular, the long duration of the response is difficult to attribute to foam alone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Production response in Bishop steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production response in Bishop steam foam pilot (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: As in Mecca, improvements in injection profile were clearly documented through several temperature surveys and neutron logs run in the wells at different points in time (Figure 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Improved vertical sweep - Bishop observation well T5 (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Improved vertical sweep - Bishop observation well T5 (Patzek & Koinis, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Patzek & Koinis, 1990 PatzekT., & Koinis, M. (1990, April). Kern River Steam-Foam Pilots . Journal of Petroleum Technology , 42(04), 496–503

linkTarget.anchoringText: A steam foam pilot was initiated in 1985 after 7 years of steamflood in 4 inverted five-spot patterns, four injectors and nine producers in total (Figure 11). The aim of the pilot was to reduce steam override in this very thick (134 m) reservoir.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Map of Dome-Tumbador steam-foam pilot (Mohammadi, Van Slyke, & Ganong, 1989)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of Dome-Tumbador steam-foam pilot (Mohammadi, Van Slyke, & Ganong, 1989)

linkTarget.bib: Mohammadi, Van Slyke, & Ganong, 1989 MohammadiS., Van Slyke, D., & Ganong, B. (1989, February). Steam-Foam Pilot Project in Dome-Tumbador, Midway- Sunset Field . SPE Reservoir Engineering , 4(01), 7–16.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Foam formation was confirmed early with an increase in injection pressure in the 4 injection wells. Oil production increased from 850 bopd up to over 1,050 bopd (Figure 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Production response in Dome-Tumbador pilot (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production response in Dome-Tumbador pilot (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990 MohammadiS., & Tenzer, J. (1990). Steam-Foam Pilot Project at Dome-Tumbador, Midway Sunset Field: Part 2. Paper SPE 20201 presented at the SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium. Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA , 22-25 April.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Temperature logs and repeated neutron logs run in the pilot suggested that steam injection profiles had been improved by the foam and that new intervals had been flooded by the steam (Figure 13). An incremental recovery of 6.0% OOIP (1,234,000 bbl) for the pilot and surrounding wells was reportedly achieved which corresponds to 2.4 kg of surfactant per incremental bbl of oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Improved vertical sweep - Dome-Tumbador observation well O-2 (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Improved vertical sweep - Dome-Tumbador observation well O-2 (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990)

linkTarget.bib: Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990 MohammadiS., & Tenzer, J. (1990). Steam-Foam Pilot Project at Dome-Tumbador, Midway Sunset Field: Part 2. Paper SPE 20201 presented at the SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium. Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA , 22-25 April.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The issue of temperature and in particular of the maximum applicable temperature for steam foam is very sensitive. As demonstrated by Table 10 and Figure 14, steam foam has mostly been used below 250°C. Of the tests above 250°C, one (Bachaquero) corresponds to cyclic injections (Robaina & Ziritt, 1988) for which surfactants stability is not as important; one (Cat Canyon) failed maybe due to temperature (Eson & Cook, 1989); and three over 300°C in Shengli correspond to high temperature gas foam with steam rather than to steam foam.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Ranges of temperatures for field tests

formatted-caption.caption-text: Ranges of temperatures for field tests

linkTarget.anchoringText: There is relatively little information on how far foam can propagate into the reservoir. Figure 15 reproduced from Mohammadi and Tenzer (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990) shows the evolution of foam volume as a function of injected surfactant. According to this interepretation foam can propagate at large distances into the reservoir provided that enough surfactant is injected.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Foam propagation in field tests (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990). The curve labeled Midway Sunset corresponds to the Dome Tumbador field test; the curve labeled Kern River corresponds to the Bishop and Mecca field tests.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Foam propagation in field tests (Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990). The curve labeled Midway Sunset corresponds to the Dome Tumbador field test; the curve labeled Kern River corresponds to the Bishop and Mecca field tests.

linkTarget.bib: Mohammadi & Tenzer, 1990 MohammadiS., & Tenzer, J. (1990). Steam-Foam Pilot Project at Dome-Tumbador, Midway Sunset Field: Part 2. Paper SPE 20201 presented at the SPE/DOE Enhanced Oil Recovery Symposium. Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA , 22-25 April.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Steam foam surface injection facilities have been described in several papers (Eson & Cook, 1989), (Bautista & Waninger, 1993), (Mohammadi, Van Slyke, & Ganong, 1989), (Ploeg & Duerksen, 1985) etc.; Figure 16 from (Bautista & Waninger, 1993) presents one example. Surfactant and gas are simply added at the wellhead.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Steam foam surface facilities schematic (Bautista & Waninger, 1993)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Steam foam surface facilities schematic (Bautista & Waninger, 1993)

linkTarget.bib: Bautista & Waninger, 1993 BautistaL., & Waninger, E. (1993). The Effect of Steam/Foam Injection in a Steamflood Experiencing Downdip Steam Migration. Paper SPE 25783 presented at the SPE International Thermal Operations Symposium. Bakersfield, California, USA , 8-10 February.
